sect1.title: Obtaining a package
sect1.para: At this time, only source packages are available. They are available from www.rtlad.org.

sect1.title: Dependencies
sect1.para:
Dryad uses a small number of external libraries to facilitate more complex functionality. In particular, it is reliant on:
PCRE -- The Perl compatible regular expression library.
libESMTP -- A library providing SMTP client functionality. (This is required to build the email response module.)
libPThread -- This should simply be a part of your operating system. Linux users: it is strongly recommended that you upgrade to a version of glibc that supports NPTL threads, rather than the old, inefficient, LinuxThreads.

sect1.title: Building Dryad
sect1.para:
Dryad uses the standard GNU auto tools, so it is a fairly standard install process:
./configure make su -c 'make install'

sect2.title: OpenBSD
sect2.para: If you are using the gcc-2.95 compiler that ships with OpenBSD, you will need to specify --disable-isoc option to ./configure when building libESMTP, as it is not in the ports tree as of OpenBSD 3.5

When running ./configure for Dryad, be sure that /usr/loca/libs is specified in the search path of the linker. Also, be sure that /usr/local/include and /usr/local/share/libtool/libltdl are in the search path for includes.

sect2.title: Win32
sect2.para: Because Windows provides a very different set of APIs, it is required that some sort of UNIX compatibility layer be provided. As of this writing, Dryad has only been tested with Cygwin, however it should build with MicroSoft's Services For Unix. Regardless of which environment is chosen, at least some of the requisite libraries will need to be built from sources. If you are using Cygwin, when building libESMTP, you will need to specify --enable-emulate-getadrinfo to ./configure.

sect2.title: Other platforms
sect2.para: Dryad should build on any platform that supports its dependencies, however, we have not yet had the oppertunity to test any others. It is our belief that the Dryad codebase is both 32 and 64 bit safe, as it is developed and tested on both types of platform. Should you require Dryad ported to another platform, feel free to contact the development team about sponsoring such an effort.
